channel.title: NYT > Top Stories
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: How a Record Cash Haul Vanished for Senate Republicans
item.description: The campaign arm of Senate Republicans had collected $181.5 million by the end of July — but spent 95 percent of it. A big investment in digital, and hyperaggressive tactics, have not paid off.
item.dc:creator: Shane Goldmacher
item.media:credit: Emil Lippe for The New York Times
item.media:description: Senator Rick Scott of Florida oversaw an enormous wave of spending on digital ads at the National Republican Senatorial Committee.

item.title: In Palm Springs, L.G.B.T.Q. Voters Could Sway a Key House Race
item.description: Representative Ken Calvert, a long-serving Republican, is facing a tough re-election race in a redrawn district that now includes Palm Springs, proclaimed to be the gayest city in America.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Lai
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
item.media:credit: Adam Perez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Palm Springs was known in its early days as a retreat for Hollywood celebrities and later became home to thousands of gay men who relocated there during the AIDS epidemic.

item.title: Abortion Pill Providers Work to Broaden Access Post-Roe Decision
item.description: These new efforts, which test the legal boundaries, have sprung up since the Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade and many states restricted abortion.
item.dc:creator: Pam Belluck
item.media:credit: Kelly Burgess for The New York Times
item.media:description: New medication abortion services are springing up and existing services are expanding, some adopting new practices that increase access while pushing the envelope of regulations and laws.

item.title: Renewed Shelling Puts Ukraine’s Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Plant at Risk
item.description: The International Atomic Energy Agency was still cautiously optimistic that “permanently” stationing two experts at the Zaporizhzhia nuclear power plant would help avert disaster.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora and Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: Jim Huylebroek for The New York Times
item.media:description: A delegation from the International Atomic Energy Agency, returning from an inspection of the Zaporizhzhia nuclear power plant, at a Ukrainian-controlled checkpoint.

item.title: At Mikhail Gorbachev’s Funeral, Russians Mourn in Silent Protest
item.description: At the funeral of Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the last Soviet leader, the size of the crowds signaled the depth of the regret about the undoing of the freedoms that his tenure initiated.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins and Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:credit: Evgenia Novozhenina/Reuters
item.media:description: Honor guards standing next to the coffin of Mikhail S. Gorbachev on Saturday at the House of the Unions in Moscow.

item.title: Serena Williams Loses in Three Thrilling Sets to Ajla Tomljanovic
item.description: “It’s been the most incredible ride and journey I’ve ever been on in my life,” Williams, wiping tears, said on court after the match.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Futterman
item.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times

item.title: How Ajla Tomljanovic Faced Down Serena Williams and 24,000 Others
item.description: On the advice of her father, Tomljanovic channeled Kevin Costner to beat the six-time U.S. Open champion in front of a raucous, partisan crowd in Arthur Ashe Stadium.
item.dc:creator: David Waldstein
item.media:credit: Corey Sipkin/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Ajla Tomljanovic played one of the best matches of her career against Serena Williams.

item.title: NASA Scrubs Second Artemis I Launch Attempt
item.description: Engineers were unable to resolve a hydrogen leak, which led the launch director to call off Saturday’s flight.
item.dc:creator: Kenneth Chang
item.media:credit: Cristobal Herrera-Ulashkevich/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: The Artemis I rocket on the launchpad early Saturday, its second launch attempt.

item.title: ‘That Nurse Should Be Alive’: How Police Delays Left a Suspect at Large
item.description: The New York Police Department let a suspect in a Brooklyn rape case slip through its grasp. A month later he was arrested in connection with the murder of a nurse in Queens.
item.dc:creator: Ashley Southall
item.media:credit: Go Nakamura for The New York Times
item.media:description: A memorial sprang up outside the home of Samantha Stewart after she was found dead in Queens in July 2018.

item.title: Could Student Loan Forgiveness Send Borrowers Without Degrees Back to School?
item.description: Millions took on debt for college but left without graduating, making it harder to repay their loans. Will the Biden administration’s relief plan get them to try again?
item.dc:creator: Eliza Fawcett and Jacey Fortin
item.media:credit: An Rong Xu for The New York Times
item.media:description: According to one estimate, about 15 percent of the federal loan debt currently in repayment is held by people with no degree.

item.title: Student Loan Forgiveness Is Complicated, Because This Is America
item.description: Instead of making higher education free, we subsidize it later through repayment plans and attempts at debt cancellation. The complexity is disrespectful.
item.dc:creator: Ron Lieber
item.media:credit: Robert Neubecker

item.title: Beware of Scammers Trying to Capitalize on Student Loan Forgiveness
item.description: The recent action on student debt is fodder for spam callers, who often try to trick borrowers into paying for loan cancellation.
item.dc:creator: Ann Carrns
item.media:credit: Till Lauer

item.title: You’ve Seen a Bodega Cat. How About a Barber Shop Rooster?
item.description: New York City’s beloved bodega cats are internet famous. But other animals — birds, snakes and even pigs — are also at home in neighborhood shops.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Genova

item.title: Republicans Are Showing Contempt for the Rules
item.description: The party is turning against a political commitment to fairness.
item.dc:creator: Jamelle Bouie
item.media:credit: Mark Peterson for The New York Times

item.title: Women Are So Fired Up to Vote, I’ve Never Seen Anything Like It
item.description: Since Roe v. Wade was overturned, women have registered to vote in incredible numbers.
item.dc:creator: Tom Bonier
item.category: Dobbs v Jackson Women's Health Organization (Supreme Court Decision)
item.media:credit: Dolly Faibyshev for The New York Times

item.title: Does Biden Really Believe We Are in a Crisis of Democracy?
item.description: The president’s strategy and rhetoric makes more sense if he doesn’t.
item.dc:creator: Ross Douthat
item.category: Dobbs v Jackson Women's Health Organization (Supreme Court Decision)
item.media:credit: Oliver Contreras for The New York Times

item.title: Wonking Out: The Nightmare After Gorbachev
item.description: Why did Russia’s economy do so poorly?
item.dc:creator: Paul Krugman
item.media:credit: Mark Henley/Panos Pictures, via R​edux

item.title: ‘House of the Dragon’ Is Less Sexist and Racist. But Is it Good?
item.description: The showrunners say they’ve heard and responded to criticism of ‘Game of Thrones,” but some say that has made the new show boring.
item.dc:creator: Jeff Yang
item.category: The Lord of the Rings: The Rings of Power (TV Program)

item.title: The Post-Colonoscopy Male Friendship Test
item.description: What the pandemic, parenthood and nomadism took away from my life, I replaced with surprisingly intimate connections with other men.
item.dc:creator: Boris Fishman
item.media:credit: Illustration by Frank Augugliaro. Photographs by Getty Images

item.title: Education in America: School Is for Social Mobility
item.description: If politics is the art of the possible, perhaps the biggest silver lining of these past two years has been to redefine what is possible.
item.dc:creator: John N. Friedman
item.media:credit: Illustration by Chloe Scheffe; photographs by Internet Archive; the Met Collection; Jordan Graff and Robo Wunderkind, via Unsplash; and Calsidyrose and Vacuumfan7072, via Wikimedia Commons

item.title: What Is Owed to Pakistan, Now One-Third Underwater
item.description: The Global North can help Pakistan by taking responsibility for the losses and damages of extreme weather fueled in part by the burning of fossil fuels.
item.dc:creator: Fatima Bhutto
item.media:credit: Husnain Ali/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A flooded residential area in the Dadu district of Sindh Province.

item.title: What Is a ‘Fake’ Artist in 2022?
item.description: Firestorms over the “virtual rapper” FN Meka and faceless artists on Spotify have sparked conversations about alienation and creative agency.

item.title: Are You Ready for Your Fall Booster?
item.description: Tell us about it.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Beefcake, Goethe’s Boswell and the Greeks
item.description: Our critic recommends old and new books.
item.dc:creator: Molly Young

item.title: How Many Drinks a Week Are Safe? Canada Considers a Much Lower Limit
item.description: Research to update Canada’s drinking guideline has found that there are no health benefits, only dangers, from alcohol.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:credit: Ian Austen/The New York Times
item.media:description: Research has found that consuming more than six drinks per week greatly increases health risks.

item.title: Chile Votes on Constitution That Would Enshrine Record Number of Rights
item.description: In a single ballot on Sunday, Chileans will decide on abortion, universal health care, rights for nature and a record expansion of constitutional rights.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas
item.media:credit: Tomas Munita for The New York Times
item.media:description: Copies of the proposed constitution were handed out last week in Constitution Square, in front of La Moneda, where the president’s offices are housed.

item.title: As Britain Prepares for a New Leader, Tensions With Allies Loom
item.description: Comments from the front-runner for prime minister, Liz Truss, suggest bumpier relations with Europe and the U.S. if she wins, with Northern Ireland getting in the way of the “special relationship.”
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:credit: Kirsty Wigglesworth/Associated Press
item.media:description: Liz Truss addressed Conservative Party members last week in London. The outcome of the party’s vote for prime minister will be announced on Monday.

item.title: Marilyn Loden, Who Championed a Feminist Metaphor, Dies at 76
item.description: She was asked to speak at a conference in 1978 about barriers faced by women in the workplace. She noted a barrier she called “the glass ceiling.”
item.dc:creator: Penelope Green

item.title: A Volcano Erupted Without Warning. Now, Scientists Know Why.
item.description: A new study explains how Nyiragongo, a volcano in the Democratic Republic of Congo, was relatively quiet before its eruption last year took everyone by surprise.
item.dc:creator: Robin George Andrews
item.media:credit: Alex Miles/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The Mount Nyiragongo volcano near Goma, Democratic Republic of Congo, erupting on May 22, 2021.

item.title: Why Is Pickleball So Popular?
item.description: Everyone and their mother seems to be playing. What’s the draw — and is it really a workout?
item.dc:creator: Juno DeMelo
item.media:credit: Caleb Thal for The New York Times

item.title: What to Know About the New Covid Booster Shots
item.description: New shots targeting the latest version of the Omicron variant will be available soon. When should you get yours? Here’s what experts recommend.
item.dc:creator: Dani Blum
item.media:credit: Charity Rachelle for The New York Times
item.media:description: The new shots target the Omicron subvariant BA.5, the dominant version of the virus.

item.title: As Serena Williams Plays Her Final Matches, a Generation Is Inspired
item.description: Women across the country have seen their own lives reflected in the triumphs and trials of the tennis superstar. Cue the swell of emotion.
item.dc:creator: Alisha Haridasani Gupta
item.media:credit: Michelle V. Agins/The New York Times

item.title: Why We Get Motion Sick, and How to Stop It
item.description: Experts say prevention is the best cure.
item.dc:creator: Melinda Wenner Moyer
item.media:credit: Illustration by Guillem Casasus; Photograph by Getty Images

item.title: How to Stay Hydrated in a Heat Wave
item.description: Many countries across the globe are facing dangerously high temperatures. Here’s what to do to stay safe.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Seo
item.media:credit: Getty Images

item.title: Heilung Puts a Heavy Metal Twist on the Sound of the Vikings
item.description: The band Heilung performs on replica instruments to recreate the sound world of pre-Christian Europe and bring it into the modern age.
item.dc:creator: Imogen West-Knights
item.media:credit: David B. Torch for The New York Times
item.media:description: Members of the band Heilung at the beach near the Viking burial mounds in Borre, Norway. Clockwise from top: Maria Franz, Christopher Juul and Kai Uwe Faust.
